nodes.documentation:
@title FixidityLib
@author Gadi Guy, Alberto Cuesta Canada
@notice This library provides fixed point arithmetic with protection against
overflow.
All operations are done with uint256 and the operands must have been created
with any of the newFrom* functions, which shift the comma digits() to the
right and check for limits, or with wrap() which expects a number already
in the internal representation of a fraction.
When using this library be sure to use maxNewFixed() as the upper limit for
creation of fixed point numbers. Use maxFixedMul(), maxFixedDividend() and
maxFixedAdd() if you want to be certain that those operations don't
overflow.
nodes.name: FixidityLib

nodes.documentation: @notice Number of positions that the comma is shifted to the right.
nodes.name: digits
fixed1
wrap

nodes.documentation: @notice Unwraps the uint256 inside of a Fraction struct.
nodes.name: unwrap

nodes.documentation:
@notice The amount of decimals lost on each multiplication operand.
@dev Test mulPrecision() equals sqrt(fixed1)
nodes.name: mulPrecision

nodes.documentation:
@notice Maximum value that can be represented in a uint256
@dev Test maxUint256() equals 2^256 -1
nodes.name: maxUint256
maxNewFixed
maxFixedAdd
maxFixedMul
maxFixedDividend
newFixed

nodes.documentation:
@notice Converts a uint256 in the fixed point representation of this
library to a non decimal. All decimal digits will be truncated.
nodes.name: fromFixed

typeDescriptions.typeString: function (struct FixidityLib.Fraction memory,struct FixidityLib.Fraction memory) pure returns (struct FixidityLib.Fraction memory)

nodes.documentation:
@notice Converts two uint256 representing a fraction to fixed point units,
equivalent to multiplying dividend and divisor by 10^digits().
@dev
Test newFixedFraction(maxFixedDividend()+1,1) fails
Test newFixedFraction(1,maxFixedDividend()+1) fails
Test newFixedFraction(1,0) fails
Test newFixedFraction(0,1) returns 0
Test newFixedFraction(1,1) returns fixed1()
Test newFixedFraction(maxFixedDividend(),1) returns maxFixedDividend()*fixed1()
Test newFixedFraction(1,fixed1()) returns 1
nodes.name: newFixedFraction
integer
fractional
add
subtract

typeDescriptions.typeString: function (struct FixidityLib.Fraction memory) pure returns (struct FixidityLib.Fraction memory)
function (struct FixidityLib.Fraction memory) pure returns (struct FixidityLib.Fraction memory)
function (struct FixidityLib.Fraction memory) pure returns (struct FixidityLib.Fraction memory)
function (struct FixidityLib.Fraction memory) pure returns (struct FixidityLib.Fraction memory)
function (struct FixidityLib.Fraction memory,struct FixidityLib.Fraction memory) pure returns (struct FixidityLib.Fraction memory)
function (struct FixidityLib.Fraction memory,struct FixidityLib.Fraction memory) pure returns (struct FixidityLib.Fraction memory)
function (struct FixidityLib.Fraction memory,struct FixidityLib.Fraction memory) pure returns (struct FixidityLib.Fraction memory)

nodes.documentation:
@notice x*y. If any of the operators is higher than maxFixedMul() it
might overflow.
@dev
Test multiply(0,0) returns 0
Test multiply(maxFixedMul(),0) returns 0
Test multiply(0,maxFixedMul()) returns 0
Test multiply(fixed1()/mulPrecision(),fixed1()*mulPrecision())
Test multiply(maxFixedMul(),maxFixedMul()) is around maxUint256()
Test multiply(maxFixedMul()+1,maxFixedMul()+1) fails
nodes.name: multiply
reciprocal
divide

nodes.documentation: @notice x > y
nodes.name: gt

nodes.documentation: @notice x >= y
nodes.name: gte

nodes.documentation: @notice x < y
nodes.name: lt

nodes.documentation: @notice x <= y
nodes.name: lte

nodes.documentation: @notice x == y
nodes.name: equals

typeDescriptions.typeString: function (struct FixidityLib.Fraction memory,struct FixidityLib.Fraction memory) pure returns (bool)

nodes.documentation: @notice x <= 1
nodes.name: isProperFraction

@title FixidityLib
@author Gadi Guy, Alberto Cuesta Canada
@notice This library provides fixed point arithmetic with protection against
overflow.
All operations are done with uint256 and the operands must have been created
with any of the newFrom* functions, which shift the comma digits() to the
right and check for limits, or with wrap() which expects a number already
in the internal representation of a fraction.
When using this library be sure to use maxNewFixed() as the upper limit for
creation of fixed point numbers. Use maxFixedMul(), maxFixedDividend() and

overflow.

userdoc.notice: This library provides fixed point arithmetic with protection against overflow. All operations are done with uint256 and the operands must have been created with any of the newFrom* functions, which shift the comma digits() to the right and check for limits, or with wrap() which expects a number already in the internal representation of a fraction. When using this library be sure to use maxNewFixed() as the upper limit for creation of fixed point numbers. Use maxFixedMul(), maxFixedDividend() and maxFixedAdd() if you want to be certain that those operations don't overflow.
